source.f936045c:
#plot function for charts
def plot_indicator(indicator, indicator2, indicator3):
    fin_loc = finland[['IndicatorName','Year','Value']][finland['IndicatorCode']==indicator]
    x_fin = fin_loc['Year']
    y_fin = fin_loc['Value']
    title = fin_loc['IndicatorName'].iloc[0]
    china_loc = china[['IndicatorName','Year','Value']][china['IndicatorCode']==indicator]
    x_china = china_loc['Year']
    y_china = china_loc['Value']
    usa_loc = usa[['IndicatorName','Year','Value']][usa['IndicatorCode']==indicator]
    x_usa = usa_loc['Year']
    y_usa = usa_loc['Value']
    
    fin_loc2 = finland[['IndicatorName','Year','Value']][finland['IndicatorCode']==indicator2]
    x_fin2 = fin_loc2['Year']
    y_fin2 = fin_loc2['Value']
    title2 = fin_loc2['IndicatorName'].iloc[0]
    china_loc2 = china[['IndicatorName','Year','Value']][china['IndicatorCode']==indicator2]
    x_china2 = china_loc2['Year']
    y_china2 = china_loc2['Value']
    usa_loc2 = usa[['IndicatorName','Year','Value']][usa['IndicatorCode']==indicator2]
    x_usa2 = usa_loc2['Year']
    y_usa2 = usa_loc2['Value']
    
    fin_loc3 = finland[['IndicatorName','Year','Value']][finland['IndicatorCode']==indicator3]
    x_fin3 = fin_loc3['Year']
    y_fin3 = fin_loc3['Value']
    title3 = fin_loc3['IndicatorName'].iloc[0]
    china_loc3 = china[['IndicatorName','Year','Value']][china['IndicatorCode']==indicator3]
    x_china3 = china_loc3['Year']
    y_china3 = china_loc3['Value']
    usa_loc3 = usa[['IndicatorName','Year','Value']][usa['IndicatorCode']==indicator3]
    x_usa3 = usa_loc3['Year']
    y_usa3 = usa_loc3['Value']
    
    plt.figure(figsize=(16,8))
    
    plt.subplot(1,3,1)
    plt.plot(x_fin,y_fin,label='Finland', color='white')
    plt.plot(x_china,y_china,label='China', color='red')
    plt.plot(x_usa,y_usa,label='USA', color='blue')
    plt.title(title)
    plt.grid(color = 'gray', linestyle = '--')
    plt.xlim(1970)
    plt.legend(loc='upper center')
    
    plt.subplot(1,3,2)
    plt.plot(x_fin2,y_fin2,label='Finland', color='white')
    plt.plot(x_china2,y_china2,label='China', color='red')
    plt.plot(x_usa2,y_usa2,label='USA', color='blue')
    plt.title(title2)
    plt.grid(color = 'gray', linestyle = '--')
    plt.xlim(1970)
    plt.legend(loc='upper center')
    
    plt.subplot(1,3,3)
    plt.plot(x_fin3,y_fin3,label='Finland', color='white')
    plt.plot(x_china3,y_china3,label='China', color='red')
    plt.plot(x_usa3,y_usa3,label='USA', color='blue')
    plt.title(title3)
    plt.grid(color = 'gray', linestyle = '--')
    plt.xlim(1970)
    plt.legend(loc='upper center')
    
    plt.show()
source.23b3562b:
print('Average GDP per capita growth annual %')
print('Finland:', finland.loc[finland['IndicatorCode'] == 'NY.GDP.PCAP.KD.ZG', 'Value'].values.astype('float').mean().round(2))
print('China:', china.loc[china['IndicatorCode'] == 'NY.GDP.PCAP.KD.ZG', 'Value'].values.astype('float').mean().round(2))
print('USA:', usa.loc[usa['IndicatorCode'] == 'NY.GDP.PCAP.KD.ZG', 'Value'].values.astype('float').mean().round(2))
source.5ccbd57c:
fingdp_1970 = finland.loc[(finland['IndicatorCode'] == 'NY.GDP.PCAP.CD') & (finland['Year'] == 1970), 'Value'].values[0].astype('int')
fingdp_2013 = finland.loc[(finland['IndicatorCode'] == 'NY.GDP.PCAP.CD') & (finland['Year'] == 2013), 'Value'].values[0].astype('int')
fingdp_pct = (fingdp_2013-fingdp_1970)/fingdp_1970*100
chngdp_1970 = china.loc[(china['IndicatorCode'] == 'NY.GDP.PCAP.CD') & (china['Year'] == 1970), 'Value'].values[0].astype('int')
chngdp_2013 = china.loc[(china['IndicatorCode'] == 'NY.GDP.PCAP.CD') & (china['Year'] == 2013), 'Value'].values[0].astype('int')
chngdp_pct = (chngdp_2013-chngdp_1970)/chngdp_1970*100
usagdp_1970 = usa.loc[(usa['IndicatorCode'] == 'NY.GDP.PCAP.CD') & (usa['Year'] == 1970), 'Value'].values[0].astype('int')
usagdp_2013 = usa.loc[(usa['IndicatorCode'] == 'NY.GDP.PCAP.CD') & (usa['Year'] == 2013), 'Value'].values[0].astype('int')
usagdp_pct = (usagdp_2013-usagdp_1970)/usagdp_1970*100
print('GDP per capita (current US$)')
print('Finland 1970: {}$ | 2013: {}$ '.format(fingdp_1970,fingdp_2013), '| change: {}%'.format(fingdp_pct.astype('int')))
print('China 1970: {}$ | 2013: {}$ '.format(chngdp_1970,chngdp_2013), '| change: {}%'.format(chngdp_pct.astype('int')))
print('USA 1970: {}$ | 2013: {}$ '.format(usagdp_1970,usagdp_2013), '| change: {}%'.format(usagdp_pct.astype('int')))
source.91ea88a5:
My goal is to find out how my home country Finland has developed since 1970 alongside the United States, which has dominated the world economy in recent decades and China, which has become the second largest economy in the recent years.  
Finland has been ranked the happiest country in the world for four years in a row in the World Happiness Report. USA ranked 14th and China 52nd in the 2021's World Happiness report.     
[Helliwell J., Layard R., Sachs J., De Neve J., Aknin L., and Wang S. (2021). World Happiness Report. Retrieved April 28, 2021 from]       (https://happiness-report.s3.amazonaws.com/2021/WHR+21_Ch2.pdf).  
The dataset includes the years 1965-2015, I use the years 1970 onwards. For some indicators the time interval is shorter.
source.f0ffb567:
# 2. Life expectancy
* Life expectancy has clearly increased in each of the countries being compared since the 1970s.
* Women are assumed to live longer than men.
source.2ad0df64:
# 4. Emissions
* China's CO2 emissions have clearly overtaken the US in the 21st century. 
* Even the slightest increase in per capita energy source consumption in China has a huge impact in CO2 emissions on a global scale.
source.d41e2af8:
# 1. GDP
* GDP per capita in Finland has been a little bit less than in the USA almost every year since 1970. The development of GDP in Finland has been much more volatile than in the USA.
* GDP per capita in China is far behind Finland and USA, but their annual GDP growth % has been much higher, so in the future China bypasses Finland and the USA if the growth continues.
source.8067fed6:
# 3. Age structure of the population
* The aging of the population will certainly pose challenges, especially in Finland, where the share of the working-age population is lower than in the USA and China, and the share of the elderly is much higher. The tax money of the working age population should be able to take care of the growing number of elderly people.
source.e8ffbecb:
# 5. The future
* Finland has been the happiest country in the world for last few years according the World Happiness Report, but can Finland hold its happiness as the population gets older? 
* How does China's economic and emission growth affect its wellbeing and happiness?
* Whether the USA will remain the pole of the world or will China overtake it?
